Question_1.Context: The study aimed to investigate the application of Lactobacillus plantarum (LP) and wheat bran (WB) on the fermentation characteristics, chemical composition, and microbial community of paper mulberry silage.
Question_1.Question: What was the objective of the study?
Question_1.A: To evaluate the effects of Lactobacillus plantarum and wheat bran on the growth of paper mulberry.
Question_1.B: To analyze the chemical composition of paper mulberry silage.
Question_1.C: To investigate the application of LP and WB on the fermentation quality of paper mulberry silage.
Question_1.D: To study the effects of different additives on the color of paper mulberry silage.
Question_1.Source: The objective of this study was to evaluate the effects of Lactobacillus plantarum and wheat bran alone or combination (LP + WB) addition on the fermentation quality and bacterial community of paper mulberry silage.

Question_2.Context: The study conducted an experiment on paper mulberry silage with different treatments including control, LP, WB, and LP + WB.
Question_2.Question: What were the treatments used in the experiment?
Question_2.C: Control, LP, WB, and LP + WB.
Question_2.Source: The silage treatments were as followed: (i) no additives (control group, CK); (ii) application of L. plantarum (LP silage); (iii) application of wheat bran additives (WB silage); (iv) combination of L. plantarum and wheat bran (LP + WB silage).

Question_3.Context: The study analyzed the chemical composition of paper mulberry silage after 60 days of ensiling.
Question_3.Question: What was the main difference observed in the chemical composition of paper mulberry silage among the treatments?
Question_3.A: No difference in any chemical composition.
Question_3.B: Higher NDF content in all treatments.
Question_3.C: Lower ADF content in WB and LP + WB treatments.
Question_3.D: Higher WSC content in LP treatment.
Question_3.Source: The WB and LP + WB treatments had higher ADF content changes rate than control and LP treatment, which could be due to acidolysis during ensiling process.

Question_4.Context: The study investigated the microbial population in paper mulberry silage after 60 days of ensiling.
Question_4.Question: Which treatment showed a significant increase in lactic acid bacteria (LAB) counts?
Question_4.Source: The WB and LP + WB treatments significantly increased LA content and decreased pH, the contents of NH3-N, AA, BA and the amount of LAB compared with control and LP treatments.

Question_5.Context: The study analyzed the bacterial community in paper mulberry silage after ensiling.
Question_5.Question: Which genus was the dominant in all silages?
Question_5.Source: At the genus levels, Lactobacillus was the dominant genus in all silages, and the proportion of Lactobacillus in LP, WB and LP + WB were 84.45%, 89.27% and 86.10%, respectively.

Question_6.Context: The study analyzed the bacterial community at the species level in paper mulberry silage.
Question_6.Question: Which species was positively correlated with lactic acid content and negatively correlated with pH?
Question_6.Source: Lactobacillus brevis was positively correlated to LA and negatively to pH, indicating that the production of LA was largely attributable to L. brevis.

Question_7.Context: The study analyzed the dynamic changes in chemical composition of paper mulberry silage before and after ensiling.
Question_7.Question: Which treatment had the lowest dynamic change in dry matter content?
Question_7.Source: The dynamic change of DM, CP and WSC losses before and after ensiling in WB and LP + WB treatments was significantly lower than control and LP treatments.

Question_8.Context: The study investigated the fermentation characteristics of paper mulberry silage.
Question_8.Question: Which treatment had the highest lactic acid content?
Question_8.Source: The WB and LP + WB treatments significantly increased LA content and decreased pH, the contents of NH3-N, AA, BA and the amount of LAB compared with control and LP treatments.

Question_9.Context: The study analyzed the microbial diversity in paper mulberry silage.
Question_9.Question: Which treatment showed the highest Shannon index?
Question_9.Source: Compared with control, inoculations with treatments significantly increased Shannon, while the highest was 2.43 of LP + WB treatment.

Question_10.Context: The study investigated the correlation between bacterial community and fermentation products in paper mulberry silage.
Question_10.Question: Which species was negatively correlated with lactic acid content and positively correlated with ammonia nitrogen content?
Question_10.Source: L. farciminis, L. ginsenosidimutans, L. maninotivorans, and L. dextrinicus were positively correlated to pH, AA content and AN/TN, but were negatively correlated to LA, WSC content and ratio of LA and AA.
